Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Research Experiences for Undergraduates in Cybersecurity, Robotics, and Software Engineering

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This funding renews a highly-successful CISE Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site at Texas Tech University. The site covers research topics in cybersecurity, robotics, and software engineering. The intellectual focus of the REU site is on addressing the underlying theoretical concepts in each research project and on developing a research proposal that can be reasonably conducted during the research period. Modeling uncertainty is a common theme within several of the research topics, with application areas that include the Smart Grid, surveillance, assistive care, reconnaissance, unmanned vehicles, climate forecasting, and irrigation management. Cross-discipline seminars will be held at the beginning of the summer to help the students get a smooth start on their research projects.

This site will introduce 30 undergraduate students (over three years) to computing research, with a goal of directing more U.S. undergraduates into graduate computing programs. The site will aid the professional development of the participating students by providing weekly educational activities, such as how to write a research paper and pursue research in ethically sound ways.

This site is co-funded by the Department of Defense in partnership with the NSF REU program.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF REU Site program, hosted at Texas Tech University, focused on providing research opportunities to students in the areas of software engineering, cybersecurity, robotics, cloud, and high performance computing. Over a three-year period, the program provided summer support for 28 students, including eleven women, five Hispanic students, and six African-American students. About half of the participants have been from Texas Tech University. Eight students have been from universities and colleges that do not provide graduate programs in computer science (Colorado College, Texas Woman’s University, Southern Utah University, Shaw University, Georgia Perimeter, Monmouth College, California State University – Channel Islands, Lindenwood University), thus providing research opportunities to students that would not normally have such opportunities within their home institutions. 

Research in the area of software engineering addressed topics such as automatic programming from specifications, self-managed software systems, and anomaly detection in software components. Research topics in the area of robotics addressed multi-agent collaboration and fault detection. Cybersecurity research included network traffic analysis for suspicious activity detection, analysis of cybersecurity data for identifying the sources of attack, and event stream processing for intrusion detection. Two medical image processing projects also addressed the integration of machine learning techniques for assisting the identification of diseases and provided students interdisciplinary research and development experiences. Three projects in the cloud computing and high performance computing space offered students experiences with real-world computing infrastructures and conducting research and development to improve the infrastructures and computing systems for more productive scientific discovery.

Student research results have resulted in nine published papers as well as four poster presentations.

Modified by: Yong Chen
